Specifically, 129 valid cases used constant-velocity assumptions without significant deviation, yielding a success rate of 129 / 139 ≈ 0.928.

The function exhibits high alignment with the current context, as it assumes uniform motion between two endpoints—consistent with the observed speed_profile (10.1–10.2 knots, coefficient of variation < 1.8%), course_change (COG varying only 2° over 250 seconds, indicating near-linear path), and heading_fluctuation (stable at 55°–57°, standard deviation ≈ 0.7°). Operational Protocol Rationale: The vessel is operating under normal transit conditions typical of cargo ships navigating structured waterways near established shipping lanes. Its consistent speed, minimal heading variation, and gradual course adjustment indicate controlled, predictable movement along a predefined curved route—common in coastal or channel navigation where vessels must follow designated paths to ensure safety and traffic separation. This behavior aligns with standard maritime navigation practices for medium-sized cargo vessels transiting confined or high-traffic waters, where stable helm control and adherence to fixed routes minimize collision risk and support efficient traffic flow. Alternative behaviors such as anchoring, maneuvering intensively, or deviating from established paths are ruled out by the sustained engine use, steady motion, and absence of abrupt changes in course or speed.
